I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the country programming mission in December 2010, the Government of the 
People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  asked  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  provide 
capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)1 to  help  the  Datang  International  Power 
Generation Company (Datang Power)2 study, pilot test, and analyze the use of carbon dioxide 
capture and storage (CCS) to reduce carbon dioxide (CO ) emission from natural gas-based 
2
combined cycle (NGCC) power plants.3 The TA was included in ADB's country operations 
business plan, 2011–2013 for the PRC.4 The concept paper was approved on 19 August 2011. 
During the fact-finding mission, an understanding was reached with the Ministry of Finance and 
Datang  Power  and  was  recorded  in  a  memorandum  of  understanding.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The PRC is now widely recognized as the largest source of greenhouse gas (GHG) 
emissions in the world.5 About half of the PRC’s CO  emissions come from the generation of 
2
electricity and heat and 25% are produced by industry. These two sources also contribute to 
more localized air pollution problems due to their heavy reliance on energy from coal. Although 
the government has taken measures to address these issues, growing demand for electricity 
and heat in urban areas has made reducing the growth of GHGs and other pollutants from the 
country’s power sector a major challenge.  
 
3.  During the 12th Five-Year Plan (2011–2015), the PRC plans to increase its installed 
power generation capacity by about 530 gigawatts (GW) through a diversified energy mix of 295 
GW  from  thermal  power  (including  16  GW  from  natural  gas-fired  power),  120  GW  from 
hydropower, 70 GW from wind power, 40 GW from nuclear power, and 5 GW from solar power. 
Apart from targeting large increases in renewable energy and carbon free nuclear energy, the 
plan emphasizes greater use of low carbon natural gas in energy mix by increasing its share 
from less than 4% of overall capacity in 2010 to over 8% by 2015.6 The government also plans 
to close a large number of old and inefficient coal-based power plants and heat-only boilers and 
to maximize the use of combined heat and power (CHP) plants. CHP and combine cycle power 
plants using natural gas are becoming increasingly attractive options for meeting stringent air 
quality and emission requirements in northern urban areas of the PRC, such as Beijing and 
Tianjin.7  
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 07 October 2011. 
2  The Datang International Power Generation Company is a state-owned enterprise. With more than 37 GW of 
installed capacity, it is one of the largest independent power producers in the PRC. It is a core subsidiary of China 
Datang Corporation, which is one of only two power generating companies in the PRC with more than 100 GW of 
installed power generation capacity. 
3  CO  capture and storage, more commonly known as CCS, refers to a suite of technologies that separates CO
2 2 
from emission sources—such as fossil fuel power plants and industrial facilities—transports it to a suitable storage 
site, and injects it deep in underground formations for storage. 
4  ADB. 2011. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2011–2013. Manila. 
5  Gases that trap heat in the atmosphere are often called GHG. Scientific studies have shown that these gases are 
responsible for global climate change. CO  is the main GHG. 
2
6  Natural gas is only half as carbon intensive as coal. A natural gas power plant will typically emit half of the CO and 
2 
only a fraction of the sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxide that a coal-based plant of equivalent capacity will. The 
natural gas consumption has been steadily rising in the PRC. In 2010, it consumed more than 100 billion cubic 
meters of natural gas. 
7  The ambient air quality standards in the PRC are not as stringent as the World Health Organization suggested 
interim targets. Revised and tighter standards are expected to be in place during the 12th Five-Year Plan.

2  
 
4.  Datang Power is planning to develop a 1,050 megawatt NGCC plant at Gaojing near 
Beijing to meet the growing electricity and heating demand in and around the city. The proposed 
NGCC plant is expected to replace a 600 megawatt coal-fired power plant that has operated for 
40 years. The new plant is to be built on the same site and will produce less emission than the 
old  plant  it  replaces  despite  its  greater  output.8 It  will  also  have  very  high  efficiency  of 
cogeneration power units of 87%. Nonetheless, it will still emit a large amount of CO  and have 
2
a deleterious impact on global climate change.  
 
5.  CCS technologies are now widely recognized as the most promising and the only nearly 
commercially viable technology available to disassociate CO emissions from fossil fuel usage 
2 
at scale. CCS has been used successfully in oil and gas industries for decades and aggressive 
international efforts are underway to demonstrate CCS in coal and natural gas-based power 
plants.  CCS  is  included  in  all  cost  effective  climate  change  mitigation  strategies  of  the 
International Energy Agency (IEA) and the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. The 
IEA estimates that CCS can contribute 19% of the emission reduction needed to constrain a rise 
in global temperature to within the agreed limit of 2 degrees celsius. According to the IEA, the 
cost of achieving the same emission reduction without CCS would be 70% higher.   
 
6.  A CCS road map developed by the IEA calls for more than 100 CCS projects to be in 
operation by 2020, half of them in developing countries. More than 70 fully integrated CCS 
projects have reached various stages of development across the world but the overwhelming 
majority  of  them  are  in  developed  countries.  Demonstrating  CCS  in  developing  countries 
dependent  on  fossil  fuels  is  now  viewed  by  all  stakeholders  as  essential  to  making  its 
deployment  likely  and  to  decarbonizing  their  power  sectors.  At  the  16th  session  of  the 
Conference of the Parties in Cancun 2010 under the United Nations Framework Convention on 
Climate  Change,  CCS  was  considered  eligible  as  a  project  activity  under  the  Clean 
Development Mechanism but several issues related to its implementation remained outstanding. 
They are expected to be resolved by end 2011 at the 17th Conference of the Parties meeting in 
Durban, South Africa.  
 
7.  Currently, the PRC does not include CCS in the portfolio of low-carbon technologies that 
it is aggressively pursuing.9  This is because CCS has not been demonstrated commercially in 
many fossil fuel power plants in the PRC or elsewhere.10 Moreover, CCS substantially increases 
the capital cost of a power plant and reduces electricity output and plant efficiency because 
additional fuel and electricity are needed to capture and store CO .11 But the PRC is adding a 
2
large amount of new fossil fuel-based power plant capacity every year—along with the large 
new volumes of CO  emissions these plants produce. The country added 58 GW to its thermal 
2
power capacity in 2010 alone. This is a compelling reason to fast-track the demonstration of 
CCS on fossil fuel power plants in the PRC as a least-cost option for CO  abatement.   
2
                                                 
8  The estimated annual emission reductions are 1,350 tons of sulfur dioxide, 2,200 tons of nitrogen oxide, and          
2 million tons of CO . 
2
9  In the PRC, low-carbon energy development is primarily aimed at improving energy intensity—reducing the amount 
of energy used per unit of gross domestic product—and scaling up renewable energy production. 
10 At the moment, only five large fully integrated operational CCS projects mainly in oil and gas exploration/ 
processing – Sleipner and Snohvit (both in Norway); In Salah (Algeria); Rangely (USA); and Weyburn – Midale 
(USA/Canada). But many such plants are either in construction or in advanced planning stage The Global Status of 
CCS: 2011 report by the Global CCS Institute suggests that of 74 large-scale CCS projects that are in various 
stages of development, 42 are in fossil fuel power plants. 
11 An ADB commissioned study in the PRC found that fitting CCS on coal-fired power plants, increases capital cost by 
25%–65%.

3
 
8.  Due to large new fossil fuel-based power plants capacity addition every year, the use of 
“CCS ready” as a planning condition also assumes greater significance in the PRC before CCS 
technologies have been demonstrated commercially.12 In future, when restrictions on carbon 
emissions  are  likely  to  be  imposed  and  enforced,  plants  without  CCS-ready  option  may 
experience carbon “lock-in” and become stranded assets.13 Including CCS readiness in the 
planning and construction of a plant at what is now a marginally incremental cost roughly 
estimated at 1%–2% of the total capital investment will allow, encourage, and assist a smooth 
CCS retrofit in the future and avoid carbon lock-in. 
 
9.  To best illustrate CCS potential, it is essential that CCS-ready projects are developed 
through a major power-generating company such as Datang Power, which is already planning 
many natural gas-based power plants during the twelfth plan. The TA will help Datang Power 
test and demonstrate the CCS-ready approach in planning and construction of the proposed 
NGCC plant near Beijing (para. 4). The TA will also look at measures to further improve the air 
pollution performance of this plant against international best practices. Reducing air pollution 
can cut the incidence of respiratory infections, heart disease, and lung cancer by around 15%.14 
Any reduction in emissions from power and heat generation provides indirect benefits to all 
residents in a project area, including the poor, who are more vulnerable to such diseases due to 
their greater exposure to outdoor air pollution.  
 
10.  ADB recognizes the importance of CCS to environmentally sustainable growth in the 
fossil fuel-based economies of its developing member countries and plays an active part in 
international CCS activities. It is a stakeholder in the Carbon Sequestration Leadership Forum 
and a member of the Global CCS Institute. It has also set up a dedicated CCS fund under its 
Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility with a contribution of A$21.5 million equivalent by 
the Global CCS Institute. The capacity development TA will complement other ongoing ADB TA 
projects and a loan for the PRC’s first integrated gasification combined cycle power plant at 
Tianjin.15  The TA will extend previous ADB interventions of CO  capture from coal-based plants 
2
to CO  capture from natural gas plants.16 
2
 
11.  The TA is consistent with (i) the strategic priority of environmentally sustainable growth 
under ADB’s Strategy 2020; (ii) ADB’s country partnership strategy (2011–2015) for the PRC,

2 2

and the Global CCS Institute. 
13 Carbon “lock-in” refers to a situation where plants will continue to emit large amount of CO  as CCS is not feasible 
2
to retrofit. Stranded asset are those that have become obsolete in advance of complete depreciation

16 CO  capture encompasses three main technologies. Precombustion technology is generally applicable in coal-
2
based plants; CO  is separated before combustion, such as in integrated gasification combined cycle (IGCC) 
2
plants. Post-combustion technology is applicable to both coal and natural gas plants; CO  is separated from 
2

concentration CO  stream.

III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The impact of the TA will be the staged application of CCS in natural gas-based power 
plants using a CCS-ready approach. The outcome of the TA will be an enhanced capacity of 
Datang Power and key stakeholders in planning, management, and implementation of natural 
gas-based CCS-ready plants. By establishing conditions necessary to make CCS-ready plants, 
the TA may lead to policy and regulatory measures that can be adopted to prompt the design, 
permitting and construction of CCS projects in the PRC.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will (i) develop a CCS road map for natural gas-based CHP plants; (ii) compare, 
pilot-test at Gaojing power plant, and select more efficient and cost-effective technology for the 
CO   capture  from  natural  gas-based  CHP  plants;  (iii)  develop  CCS  readiness  criteria  and 
2
identify priority demonstration projects and associated financing needs; (iv) assess and develop 
comprehensive  capacity  for  CCS-ready  and  retrofit  projects;  and  (v)  implement  a  public 
outreach  program.  The  detailed  activities  are  in  the  design  and  monitoring  framework   
(Appendix 1). The TA design has been kept as modular to address some key activities such as 
pilot project implementation and storage site assessment as discussed below.  
 
14.  The CCS road map development for natural gas-based plants in the PRC requires wider 
stakeholder consultation and participation. The TA has been designed and will be implemented 
in close coordination with key stakeholders, which include the Department of Climate Change in 
the National Development and Reform Commission, the Chinese Academy of Science, relevant 
research institutes, the Global CCS Institute, and other well-known international and national 
knowledge centers. The CO  capture from the natural gas-based power plant is a cost intensive 
2
and high risk component of the whole CCS chain. Selection of appropriate technology is a key 
to manage the cost and technology risks. The TA includes preparation of simulation desk 
studies to compare technologies and pilot testing of the preferred CO  capture technology by 
2
capturing about 1,500 tons of CO  per year for industrial utilization. Similarly, CO  storage 
2 2
assessment is critical to establish the CCS readiness of any plant. The storage assessment is 
included as a standalone activity in the TA design. This will allow high-level assessment of CO  
2
storage potential near the Gaojing power plant. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The estimated cost of the TA is the equivalent to $3.15 million. It is proposed that ADB 
provide the equivalent of $1.8 million on a grant basis from the Carbon Capture and Storage 
Fund18 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility, to be administered by ADB. The 
government will finance the equivalent to $1.35 million for the pilot project and provide office 
                                                 
17 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila; ADB. 2008. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2008–2010. Manila; and ADB. 
2009. Energy Policy. Manila. 
18 Established by the Global Carbon Capture and Storage Institute.

5
accommodation, transport, counterpart staff, through Datang Power. The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  Datang Power will be the executing agency and implementing agency. Counterpart staff, 
office accommodation and facilities, and transport for site visits, as required, will be provided by 
Datang Power.19 
 
17.  The TA will require a total of 10 person-months of international consulting services and 
49 person-months of national consulting services. The indicative terms of reference and the 
type of expertise for the team of consultants are in Appendix 3. ADB, in consultation with the 
executing agency, will select and engage international and national consultants in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) using 
the 80%–20% weighted quality- and cost-based selection method. The consulting firm will be 
required to submit a simplified technical proposal covering all aspects of the terms of reference. 
Equipment purchased under the TA will be turned over to Datang Power after completion of the 
TA. Any procurement of goods and services during the TA implementation using TA resources 
will be in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
18.  With inputs from the consultants, Datang Power will finalize the scope and content of the 
training and information dissemination programs during the TA implementation and submit to 
ADB for prior approval. An advance payment facility will be provided under the TA. Workshops, 
seminars, and conferences will be organized for stakeholder consultations and to discuss TA 
outputs  progressively  during  the  TA  implementation.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be 
conducted in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time).  
 
19.  The modular approach of the TA design (paras. 14 and 15) will ensure that the TA can 
adequately address the key technical tasks and associated risks by engaging relevant experts 
during the TA implementation on as need basis. Moreover, wider stakeholder participation from 
an early stage of the TA implementation will facilitate broader dissemination of TA outputs. To 
further  strengthen  the  knowledge  dissemination,  targeted  activities  are  planned  through 
development of knowledge products and services including setting up a website.  
 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months from 15 February 2012 to 15 August 2013. 
The  consultants  will  be  required  to  submit  TA  deliverables  and  progress  reports  on  time. 
Detailed requirements for deliverables and reports are included in the outline terms of reference 
for consultants. A consultation workshop will be held on the draft final report covering all aspects 
of the TA (Appendix 3). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION  
21.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,800,000 to the People’s Republic of China to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Carbon Capture and Storage Fund under the Clean Energy 
Financing Partnership Facility for the Study on Carbon Capture and Storage in Natural Gas-
Based Power Plants.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The capacity development technical assistance (TA) will be implemented under the 
overall  supervision,  oversight,  and  day-to-day  coordination  and  guidance  of  the  Datang 
International Power Generation Company (Datang Power). TA implementation will be closely 
coordinated  with  stakeholders,  especially  during  the  firming  up  of  the  TA  outputs.  These 
stakeholders will include the Department of Climate Change in the National Development and 
Reform Commission, the Chinese Academy of Science, relevant research institutes, the Global 
CCS Institute in Australia, and other well-known international and national knowledge centers. 
The team of international consultants (10 person-months) will coordinate their work with the 
national consultants (49 person-months). The international consultants will have expertise in (i) 
carbon capture and storage (CCS) strategy development; (ii) technical areas along the whole 
CCS  value  chain,  especially  post-combustion  capture  and  storage  from  natural  gas-based 
plants; (iii) energy economics; and (iv) financial modeling and analysis. The national consultants 
will have expertise similar to that of the international experts as well as in-depth knowledge on 
local regulations and ongoing CCS activities in the People's Republic of China (PRC). The 
international CCS expert will be the team leader and the national CCS technical expert in 
capture technology will be the deputy team leader. Together, they will coordinate the activities of 
all the consultants. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
2.  Carbon capture and storage expert and team leader (3.0 person-months). The team 
leader will be responsible for pulling together outputs from other international and national 
experts in a coherent manner covering all areas of the TA. The deputy team leader will assist in 
ensuring proper coordination among international and national consultants. The team leader 
should have a postgraduate degree in engineering or another relevant field and at least 15 
years of professional experience in the energy sector or the oil and the gas industry, including at 
least 3 years of experience with CCS related work. The team leader will also undertake the 
following tasks: 
(i)  The leader will review and assess CCS developmental activities worldwide and 
the activities being carried out in the PRC under ongoing programs, including 
previous ADB TA. 
(ii)  He or she will capture and map out these national and international activities and 
their relevance to the TA activities.   
(iii)  The consultant will review and analyze previous studies, policies, and initiatives 
in other countries and capture lessons from these for promoting CCS activities in 
the PRC. 
(iv)  In conjunction with national consultants, she or he will critically examine the 
strategic importance of CCS for natural gas-based power and combined heat and 
power plants. 
(v)  The leader will analyze the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and constraints  
of CCS application in these plants.  
(vi)  In consultation with other national and international experts in the team, the 
leader will identify and design a framework for a CCS-ready natural gas-based 
power  plant  and  seek  stakeholder  acceptance  of  the  framework.  (The  three 
elements of CCS readiness will be a plant’s ability to capture, transport, and 
store carbon emissions.) With contributions from other team members, he or she 
will prepare a draft road map and identify gaps.  
(vii)  The leader will critically examine the relevance of the CCS-ready approach in 
natural gas-based power and cogeneration plants. She or he will review available

Appendix 3  11 
relevant recommendations and reports, in particular but not limited to those of the 
Global CCS Institute and the International Energy Agency.  
(viii)  In conjunction with other experts in the team, the leader will identify key trigger 
points that would allow future CCS retrofits on CCS-ready plants.  
(ix)  This consultant will identify institutional structures, skills, and resources needed 
to implement the proposed implementation of the CCS-ready plant(s) and future 
CCS retrofitting. He or she will also review the existing capacities and readiness 
of government planners, research institutes, regulators, and the implementing 
agency, and identify any critical shortfalls. 
(x)  The team leader will formulate, recommend, and implement a comprehensive 
capacity strengthening program to bridge the capacity gaps.  
(xi)  In detailed consultation with the executing agency and implementing agency and 
key stakeholders, she or he will develop benchmark standards and criteria for 
evaluating CCS-ready projects and setting performance indicators.  
(xii)  This expert will identify and rank a short list of potential CCS-ready plants for 
implementation in the next 35 years.  
(xiii)  He or she will coordinate tasks among team members and regularly coordinate 
with key stakeholders on TA implementation.   
(xiv)  The team leader will prepare a capacity development module, conduct capacity 
development  training  and  seminars,  and  prepare  guidelines  in  planning, 
management, and implementation of natural gas-based CCS-ready plants.   
 
3.  Carbon capture and storage technical expert—carbon dioxide capture (2.5 person-
months). The expert should have a postgraduate degree in engineering or another relevant field 
and at least 10 years of professional experience in the energy sector or the oil and gas industry, 
particularly in carbon capturing. The expert will support the team leader in relevant tasks and will 
undertake the following specific activities:  
(i)  The  expert  will  review  existing  and  planned  carbon  dioxide  (CO )  capture 
2
approaches  in  gas-based  power  plants  internationally  and  undertake  a 
comprehensive cost–benefit comparative analysis of these capture approaches 
and their strategic relevance to the PRC.   
(ii)  He or she will assist the team leader in identifying a technical road map for CCS- 
ready project(s), analyze the strategic merits of CCS-ready plant(s) and their 
relevance  to  the  PRC,  and  estimate  additional  investments  needed  for  the 
capture-ready natural gas-based power plants based on the proven capturing 
technologies. 
(iii)  She or he will develop strategic choices and potential technical routes for CCS 
demonstration and deployment, considering previous and ongoing studies and 
initiatives in this area internationally and in the PRC. The expert will summarize 
the  results  and  the  analysis  and  prepare  a  technical  road  map  for  CCS 
demonstration in gas-based power plant(s). 
(iv)  The technical expert will undertake a desk analysis of the costs of gas-based 
power plants with and without CCS, based on the recently constructed without 
CCS plants in the PRC. He or she will state the assumptions and basis for the 
CCS elements of the cost estimate and undertake the capacity assessment in 
terms of technical skills necessary in implementing CCS-ready and future CCS 
retrofit plant(s) to identify any critical gaps. The expert will propose a capacity 
strengthening plan to overcome critical capacity gaps. 
(v)  This expert will develop technical benchmark standards and criteria for identifying 
and  ranking  demonstration  sites  and  identify  additional  in-depth  technical 
analysis needed on selected demonstration sites and associated cost estimates.

12  Appendix 3 
(vi)  She or he will assist the team leader in conducting capacity assessment of the 
executing  agency  and  government  agencies  in  planning,  management,  and 
implementation of natural gas-based CCS-ready plants to identify core capacity 
development needs. 
(vii)  The technical expert will help the team leader to prepare a capacity development 
module, to conduct capacity development training and seminars, and to prepare 
guidelines in planning, management, and implementation of natural gas-based 
CCS-ready plants. 
 
4.  Carbon capture and storage technical expert—carbon dioxide storage (2.0 person-
months). The expert will assist the team leader and other technical experts in a comprehensive 
analysis of the whole CCS chain. The expert should have a postgraduate degree in engineering 
or another relevant field and at least 10 years of professional experience in the energy sector or 
the oil and gas industry, particularly in carbon storage and sequestration issues. In particular, 
the expert will focus on the CO  storage element of CCS and undertake the following tasks:  
2
(i)  The expert will review existing and planned CO  storage mapping and related 
2
activities being carried out or planned in the PRC. 
(ii)  He or she will undertake extensive analysis of the quality of CO  storage data 
2
and the reliability needed for CCS projects and evaluate available data and 
previous studies for their suitability for CCS demonstration.  
(iii)  She or he will identify and short-list potential storage sites near the Gaojing plant 
based on previous high-level storage data and assessment and the geological 
characterization of the storage site, i.e., CO  storage with enhanced oil recovery, 
2
depleted oil and gas fields, and saline reservoir formations. He or she will assess 
the short-listed storage sites and determine the priority storage site.  
(iv)  The expert will identify additional geological investigations required on the priority 
storage site and an indicative cost estimate for undertaking the studies, prepare 
detailed terms of reference, identify suitable agencies to undertake such a study, 
and provide oversight of the additional investigation.  
(v)  The expert will undertake the capacity assessment in terms of technical skills in 
implementing CCS-ready and future CCS retrofit plant(s), identify any critical 
gaps, and propose a capacity strengthening plan to overcome these gaps where 
necessary. 
(vi)  He  or  she  will  identify  measures  and  performance  indicators  to  ensure  the 
integrity  of  CO   storage  for  a  CCS  demonstration  and  identify  capacity 
2
strengthening measures. 
(vii)  The storage expert will help the team leader conduct capacity assessment of the 
executing  agency  and  government  agencies  in  planning,  management,  and 
implementation of natural gas-based CCS-ready plants to identify core capacity 
development needs. 
(viii)  She or he will assist the team leader in preparing a capacity development module, 
conducting  capacity  development  training  and  seminars,  and  preparing 
guidelines in planning, management, and implementation of natural gas-based 
CCS-ready plants. 
 
5.  Financial  analyst  (2.5  person-months).  The  expert  will  assist  the  team  leader  in 
assessing the financial viability of constructing the Gaojing plant as CCS-ready. The financial 
analyst in conjunction with other team members and under the guidance of the team leader and 
deputy team leader will clearly identify the incremental cost for CCS readiness and for future 
CCS retrofit. The financial analyst will also identify innovative financing that may make CCS 
work in the PRC. The expert should have a postgraduate degree in economics, business

Appendix 3  13 
administration, or another relevant field and at least 10 years of professional experience in the 
energy sector or the oil and gas industry. In particular, the expert will undertake the following 
tasks:  
(i)  He or she will prepare an indicative cost structure for natural gas-based power 
plants with and without CCS readiness, including base cost and physical and 
price contingencies. All assumptions must be spelled out clearly in arriving at the 
indicative costs. 
(ii)  The expert will analyze existing relevant financing mechanisms, such as the 
Clean Development Mechanism and the Climate Investment Facility, that can 
provide concessional financing or additional revenues to a CCS demonstration 
project, i.e., Clean Development Mechanism or enhanced oil recovery revenues. 
(iii)  She  or  he  will  prepare  an  indicative  financing  plan  for  the  demonstration 
project(s). This will include a  proposal for concessional financing, justification for 
concessional lending to mitigate the higher incremental costs of CCS readiness 
to an appropriate level, the potential source for this lending, and the appropriate 
counterpart funding. 
(iv)  The expert will carry out an in-depth financial analysis of the power plants with 
and without CCS, including calculation of the following key financial indicators, 
taking into account all the financial costs and benefits: financial internal rate of 
return, net present value, debt service coverage ratio, return on equity, payback 
period, and weighted average cost of capital.  
(v)  He or she will check and compare the financial viability with and without CCS 
projects and the expected impact on electricity and heating tariffs with CCS 
components. The expert will analyze the impact of concessional funding on the 
electricity tariff and the financial viability.  
(vi)  She or he will conduct a comprehensive analysis of all risks to project revenues 
and costs and the related sensitivity analysis of the financial results. 
(vii)  In conjunction with the CCS technical experts on the team, the consultant will 
identify incremental benchmark costs for making natural gas-based power plants 
capture-ready plants. 
(viii)  This  expert  will  help  the  team  leader  conduct  capacity  assessment  of  the 
executing  agency  and  government  agencies  in  planning,  management,  and 
implementation of natural gas-based CCS-ready plants to identify core capacity 
development needs. 
(ix)  The  expert  will  assist  the  team  leader  in  preparing  a  capacity  development 
module, conducting capacity development training and seminars, and preparing 
guidelines in planning, management, and implementation of natural gas-based 
CCS-ready plants. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
6.  A team of national consultants will provide 49 person-months of consulting services to 
supplement  and  support  the  international  consultants  with  similar  expertise.  The  national 
consultants team will comprise (i) one deputy team leader and CCS technical expert—capture 
technologies (9 person-months), (ii) one CCS strategy analyst (5 person-months), (iii) one CCS 
technical expert on capture technologies (10 person-months), (iv) one CCS technical expert— 
CO  storage (8 person-months), (v) one energy economist and policy analyst (5 person-months), 
2
(vi)  one  environment  and  climate  change  policy  analyst  (6  person-months),  and  (vii)  one 
national financial analyst (6 person-months). The deputy team leader will provide the planning 
and project management leadership for the national consultants. Together with the team leader 
from the international consultants, the deputy team leader will be the focal point for interacting

14  Appendix 3 
with key stakeholders and ensuring the quality of the TA output reports. All national consultants 
will have extensive knowledge of CCS development issues in the PRC. They will assist the 
respective international consultants in quickly becoming familiar with their tasks by reviewing 
relevant  reports,  analytical  data,  policies,  regulations,  and  current  strategic  thinking  and 
challenges in CCS. 
 
7.  The national consultants' terms of reference will be similar to those of the international 
consultants  and  they  will  carry  out  similar  tasks  in  coordination  with  relevant  international 
consultants. In addition, the national CCS strategy analyst will work with the international team 
leader and deputy team leader in examining the strategic importance and impacts of CCS in 
natural gas-based power and combined heat and power plants on the national energy mix and 
long-term energy security. In particular, this examination will compare and contrast CCS with 
other supply-side options such as nuclear power, wind power, and others, and evaluate the 
social and environmental impacts of the CCS deployment and its effects on electricity pricing. 
The national specialist on technology policy will also work with the international team leader and 
deputy team leader on identifying creative policies for the transfer of technology and intellectual 
property rights issues. The national environment and climate change policy analyst will assist 
the team leader and deputy team leader in preparing the national climate change action plan 
and in identifying the strategic fit of CCS in similar national plans and activities.       
 
8.  The national consultant’s coordinator will assist the project management office of the 
implementing agency and the team leader and deputy team leader in all TA management and 
administration  tasks  throughout  the  implementation  period.  The  national  consultant’s 
coordinator will ensure that the tasks of selected consultants can be coordinated and managed 
in a timely and cost-effective manner, enhancing TA implementation. 
 
C.  Deliverables  
 
9.   The consultants will submit the following reports. One copy to ADB in English and two 
copies to the executing agency and to the government in Chinese shall be submitted. The 
expected deliverables of the consulting services include but are not limited to the following:  
 
(i)  Inception report. The report will be submitted within 1 month after the TA starts. 
It will summarize the initial findings and suggest any changes needed in the TA 
approach, methodology, and time schedule. 
(ii)  Interim draft reports. These reports will be submitted within 5, 6, and 12 months 
of commencement of the TA. 
(iii)  Draft final report. The draft will be submitted within 13 months after the TA 
starts. The draft final report will include all components required in the study and 
it will cover all aspects of the TA implementation. 
(iv)  Consultation workshop. The workshop will be held following preparation of the 
draft final report to (a) present to the stakeholders the initial TA findings and 
recommendations, (b) facilitate idea exchange and collect comments, and (c) 
increase ownership and commitment to the TA recommendations. 
(v)  Final  report.  This  will  be  submitted  within  1  month  after  the  consultation 
workshop. The consultants will incorporate comments from the stakeholders in 
the final report. An executive summary will also be submitted. 
(vi)  Final workshop. The workshop will be held within 1 month after the submission 
of the final report (within 17 months after the commencement of the TA) to (a) 
present to the stakeholders the overall TA findings and recommendations, and (b)

Appendix 3  15 
share and publicly disseminate the TA outputs to representatives from various 
provinces.  
(vii)  TA  implementation  workshops.  An  inception  workshop  will  be  organized 
following engagement of all TA consultants and the midterm review and final 
workshops will be combined with the consultation and final workshops identified 
in items (iv) and (vi) above.
